Description: Carbon bound up in soil organic matter (SOM), which is composed of decomposing plants and animals, soil microbes, and the substances that soil microbes synthesize. SOC is a direct measurement of soil carbon accrual and soil health.
Final units: % mass of SOC over soil mass; when BD is also measured, % SOC will be converted to tons of SOC stored per acre to the project's specified sampling depth

Description: Size fractionation is a laboratory process that divides SOC into two groups that provide different benefits. MAOC is a more stable form of soil organic carbon that can be stored in soils for centuries.
Final units: % mass of MAOC over soil mass; when BD is also measured, % MAOC will be converted to tons of MAOC stored per acre to the project's specified sampling depth

Description: Size fractionation is a laboratory process that divides SOC into two groups that provide different benefits. POC is a form of soil organic carbon that has less longevity but is more available for providing soil nutrients.
Final units: % mass of POC over soil mass; when BD is also measured, % POC will be converted to tons of POC stored per acre to the project's specified sampling depth

Description: Nonliving carbon bound up in carbonate minerals; sometimes the dominant form of soil carbon in arid climates with alkaline soils. SIC is an important form of carbon storage for climate change mitigation; recommended only for soils with a pH over 7.
Final units: % mass of SIC over soil mass; when BD is also measured, % SIC will be converted to tons of SIC stored per acre to the project's specified sampling depth

Description: Mass of living grasses and forbs above the soil. AHB serves as a measure of forage productivity; turns into soil carbon over time through decomposition.
Final units: Tons of dry biomass produced per acre per year

Description: Mass of living roots produced by grasses and forbs. HRB contributes to soil health; turns into soil carbon over time through decomposition.
Final units: Tons of dry herbaceous root biomass per acre

Description: Mass of living trees and shrubs above the soil. AWB represents longer-term carbon storage in trunks and branches
Final units: Tons of aboveground woody biomass per acre

Description: Mass of tree and shrub roots. WRB contributes to soil health and longer-term carbon storage in woody roots.
Final units: Tons of woody root biomass per acre

Description: The mass of dry soil for a given volume. BD is related to compaction and aeration which influence water infiltration, root penetration, and microbial habitat
Final units: Tons of dry soil per acre to the project's specified sampling depth

Description: The proportion of sand, silt, and clay minerals in the soil. Soil texture provides information on how soils interact with and potentially stabilize carbon. Clayey soils hold water and nutrients tightly and more efficiently store carbon, but can also cause poor drainage and compaction if present in high amounts. Sandy soils drain water quickly and have good aeration but hold fewer nutrients and moisture and are slower to gain carbon compared to finer soils.
Final units: % sand, % silt, % clay

Description: The proportion of sand, silt, and clay minerals in the soil. Soil texture provides information on how soils potentially interact with and stabilize carbon. Clayey soils hold water and nutrients tightly and more efficiently store carbon, but can also cause poor drainage and compaction if present in high amounts. Sandy soils drain water quickly and have good aeration but hold fewer nutrients and moisture and are slower to gain carbon compared to finer soils.

The proportion of sand, silt, and clay minerals in the soil. Soil texture provides information on how soils potentially interact with and stabilize carbon. Clayey soils hold water and nutrients tightly and more efficiently store carbon, but can also cause poor drainage and compaction if present in high amounts. Sandy soils drain water quickly and have good aeration but hold fewer nutrients and moisture and are slower to gain carbon compared to finer soils.
The acidity or alkalinity of soil. pH impacts the nutrient availability, microbes, and plant dynamics that in turn regulate the amount of carbon entering and cycling in the soil.
Final units: 0-14 where <7 is acidic and >7 is alkaline

Description: Mineral Associated Organic Nitrogen refers to organic nitrogen compounds that are closely bound to soil minerals, such as clay and silt. This association protects the nitrogen from rapid decomposition, making it a more stable and long-term nitrogen reserve in the soil that slowly becomes available to plants.
Final units: % mass of MAON over soil mass

Description: Total soil nitrogen refers to the complete amount of nitrogen present in the soil, including both organic forms (like decomposing plant and animal material) and inorganic forms (such as ammonium and nitrate). It represents the soil’s overall nitrogen reserve available for microbial activity and, eventually, plant uptake.
Final units: % mass of total soil nitrogen over soil mass

Description: Cation exchange capacity is a measure of how well soil can hold and exchange positively charged micronutrients (i.e. Ca, Mg). Soils with higher CEC can store more of these essential nutrients, making them more available to plants over time.
Final units: Number of cations (milliequivalents) that can be held and exchanged in 100g of soil

Description: The CO₂ respiration test measures how much carbon dioxide is released from soil over a set period, indicating the level of potential microbial activity. Higher CO₂ levels usually mean a more active, living soil with better organic matter breakdown and nutrient cycling.
Final units: Parts per million

Description: Nitrate is a highly available form of nitrogen in the soil that plants readily absorb and use for growth. Nitrate can easily leach from the soil into groundwater, making timely application and monitoring important for both crop health and environmental protection.
Final units: Parts per million

Description: A soil macronutrient essential for energy transfer, root development, and early plant growth. While it often exists in unavailable forms in this soil, this is a measure of available P accessible to plants to support photosynthesis and flowering.
Final units: Parts per million

Description: A soil macronutrient that supports overall plant health by regulating water uptake, activating enzymes for photosynthesis, and improving resistance to drought and disease.
Final units: Parts per million

Description: Soil micronutrients (S, Ca, Mg, Na, Zn, Fe, Mn, Cu) are essential elements required by plants in very small amounts to support critical functions such as growth, reproduction, and resistance to stress. Though needed in trace quantities, their absence can significantly impair plant health and development.
Final units: Parts per million

Though needed in trace quantities, their absence can significantly impair plant health and development.
Final units: Parts per million
